slide.title: EUS-guided cysto-gastrostomy: indication, timing & technique
slide.notes: Good afternoon. Thanks for the kind introduction. It is my honor to be here.
slide.notesNormalized: good afternoon. thanks for the kind introduction. it is my honor to be here.
slide.notesHtml:
Good afternoon.

Thanks for the kind introduction.

It is my honor to be here.
slide.text: EUS-guided cysto-gastrostomy: indication, timing & technique Seong-Hun Kim Department of Internal Medicine, Chonbuk National University Medical School and Hospital, Jeonju, Korea Session 3. EUS-guided Pseudocyst Drainage & Necrosectomy

slide.title: Pancreatic Pseudocyst ?
slide.notes: According to the Atlanta Classification that was amended in 2012, acute fluid collection can mature into a pseudocyst, generally after 4 weeks. A pseudocyst is an encapsulated collection of fluid with a well-defined inflammatory wall, which contains minimal necrosis, or even none. Although cysto-gastrostomy is also performed for necrosectomy of WOPN, but this lecture will focus on the indication, timing and standard techniques used for that of pseudocyst.
slide.notesNormalized: according to the atlanta classification that was amended in 2012, acute fluid collection can mature into a pseudocyst, generally after 4 weeks. a pseudocyst is an encapsulated collection of fluid with a well-defined inflammatory wall, which contains minimal necrosis, or even none. although cysto-gastrostomy is also performed for necrosectomy of wopn, but this lecture will focus on the indication, timing and standard techniques used for that of pseudocyst.
slide.notesHtml:
According to the Atlanta Classification that was amended in 2012, acute fluid collection can mature into a pseudocyst, generally after 4 weeks.

A pseudocyst is an encapsulated collection of fluid with a well-defined inflammatory wall, which contains minimal necrosis, or even none.

Although cysto-gastrostomy is also performed for necrosectomy of WOPN, but this lecture will focus on the indication, timing and standard techniques used for that of pseudocyst.
slide.text: Pancreatic Pseudocyst ? The Johns Hopkins University Revised Atlanta Classification of acute pancreatitis-associated fluid collection 2012’ Bronte A. Holt, etc. GIE, 2015

slide.title: Case 81/Female Acute biliary pancreatitis
slide.notes: Not all types of pancreatitis need intervention. This 81-year-old woman was hospitalized with severe acute pancreatitis with acute peripancreatic fluid collection, but she was nearly completely healed within 8 weeks just with conservative management. In general, pseudocyst develops in 6% to 34% of acute pancreatitis, but only a proportion are symptomatic, and many resolve spontaneously.
slide.notesNormalized: not all types of pancreatitis need intervention. this 81-year-old woman was hospitalized with severe acute pancreatitis with acute peripancreatic fluid collection, but she was nearly completely healed within 8 weeks just with conservative management. in general, pseudocyst develops in 6% to 34% of acute pancreatitis, but only a proportion are symptomatic, and many resolve spontaneously.
slide.notesHtml:
Not all types of pancreatitis need intervention.

This 81-year-old woman was hospitalized with severe acute pancreatitis with acute peripancreatic fluid collection, but she was nearly completely healed within 8 weeks just with conservative management.

In general, pseudocyst develops in 6% to 34% of acute pancreatitis, but only a proportion are symptomatic, and many resolve spontaneously.
slide.text: Case 81/Female Acute biliary pancreatitis Admission After 8 wks. Pseudocyst develops in 6% to 34% of acute pancreatitis.

slide.text: The type of procedure in management of Pseudocyst

slide.title: The Management of Pseudocyst ?
slide.notes: These are the ways of pseudocyst management. First, the pseudocyst resection, second, the percutaneous approach, and third, the surgical cystogastrostomy and endoscopic cystogastrostomy.
slide.notesNormalized: these are the ways of pseudocyst management. first, the pseudocyst resection, second, the percutaneous approach, and third, the surgical cystogastrostomy and endoscopic cystogastrostomy.
slide.notesHtml:
These are the ways of pseudocyst management.

First, the pseudocyst resection, second, the percutaneous approach, and third, the surgical cystogastrostomy and endoscopic cystogastrostomy.
slide.text:
The Management of Pseudocyst ? Surgery (Pseudocyst resection) Percutaneous approach Cystogastrostomy Surgical cystogastrostomy Endoscopic cystogastrostomy Conventional cystogastrostomy EUS-guided cystogastrostomy
JOP. J Pancreas (Online) 2008

slide.title: Case 58/M Acute alcoholic pancreatitis
slide.notes: This 58-year-old male patient had peripancreatic fluid collection in the middle of his abdomen, so endoscopic approach was impossible. We therefore took the percutaneous approach.
slide.notesNormalized: this 58-year-old male patient had peripancreatic fluid collection in the middle of his abdomen, so endoscopic approach was impossible. we therefore took the percutaneous approach.
slide.notesHtml:
This 58-year-old male patient had peripancreatic fluid collection in the middle of his abdomen, so endoscopic approach was impossible.

We therefore took the percutaneous approach.
slide.text: Case 58/M Acute alcoholic pancreatitis

slide.title: EUS-guided cysto-gastrostomy?
slide.notes: Recently, the EUS-guided cysto-gastrostomy has been performed as a first-line treatment for pancreatic pseudocyst.
slide.notesNormalized: recently, the eus-guided cysto-gastrostomy has been performed as a first-line treatment for pancreatic pseudocyst.
slide.notesHtml: Recently, the EUS-guided cysto-gastrostomy has been performed as a first-line treatment for pancreatic pseudocyst.
slide.text: EUS-guided cysto-gastrostomy? http://endoscopedia.com/2015

slide.title: EUS-guided cysto-gastrostomy?
slide.notes: EUS-guided cysto-gastrostomy has similar efficacy with surgical cystogastrostomy but has greater benefits such as shorter hospital stays, fewer adverse events, better physical and mental health outcomes, and greater cost effectiveness.
slide.notesNormalized: eus-guided cysto-gastrostomy has similar efficacy with surgical cystogastrostomy but has greater benefits such as shorter hospital stays, fewer adverse events, better physical and mental health outcomes, and greater cost effectiveness.
slide.notesHtml: EUS-guided cysto-gastrostomy has similar efficacy with surgical cystogastrostomy but has greater benefits such as shorter hospital stays, fewer adverse events, better physical and mental health outcomes, and greater cost effectiveness.
slide.text: EUS-guided cysto-gastrostomy? Compared with surgical cystogastrostomy similar efficacy shorter hospital stays fewer adverse events better physical and mental health outcomes greater cost effectiveness Holt BA, Varadarajulu S. GIE 2015

slide.title: EUS-guided cysto-gastrostomy?
slide.notes: In addition, in comparison to the conventional cystogastrostomy without EUS, this method enables real-time observation, so it could secure the puncture route, characterize the lesion, lower the possibilities of complications and improve the success rates.
slide.notesNormalized: in addition, in comparison to the conventional cystogastrostomy without eus, this method enables real-time observation, so it could secure the puncture route, characterize the lesion, lower the possibilities of complications and improve the success rates.
slide.notesHtml: In addition, in comparison to the conventional cystogastrostomy without EUS, this method enables real-time observation, so it could secure the puncture route, characterize the lesion, lower the possibilities of complications and improve the success rates.
slide.text: EUS-guided cysto-gastrostomy? Compared with Conventional cystogastrostomy Overcome the “blind” approach Secure puncture-route: Bulging(x) Characterization ↑ (cystic tumor, peri-pancreatic collection) Risk of Perforation and Bleeding ↓ the technical success rates ↑

slide.title: Case 40/F When is the proper time for EUS-guided cystogastrostomy?
slide.titleNormalized: case 40/f when is the proper time for eus-guided cystogastrostomy?
slide.notes: This is a 40-year-old male patient with acute pancreatitis. After 4 weeks of conservative management, a well-matured pseudocyst is formed. If pseudocyst is not matured, we need to delay as long as possible, and we have to perform only when indicated!
slide.notesNormalized: this is a 40-year-old male patient with acute pancreatitis. after 4 weeks of conservative management, a well-matured pseudocyst is formed. if pseudocyst is not matured, we need to delay as long as possible, and we have to perform only when indicated!

slide.text: Case 40/F When is the proper time for EUS-guided cystogastrostomy? After 4wks Admission Delay as long as possible Perform only when indicated!

slide.title: Indications for Drainage of Pseudocyst ?
slide.notes: Then, what would be the relevant indications? Let’s look at a few cases.
slide.notesNormalized: then, what would be the relevant indications? let’s look at a few cases.
slide.notesHtml: Then, what would be the relevant indications? Let’s look at a few cases.
slide.text: Indications for Drainage of Pseudocyst ?

slide.title: Case 41/M – duodenal obstruction
slide.notes: This is a 41-year-old male, and we could see 2 pseudocysts on the CT. After 7 weeks, he was going through abdominal distension and vomiting, and we could see large distension of the stomach and obstruction of duodenum due to pseudocyst. This patient had an indication of drainage.
slide.notesNormalized: this is a 41-year-old male, and we could see 2 pseudocysts on the ct. after 7 weeks, he was going through abdominal distension and vomiting, and we could see large distension of the stomach and obstruction of duodenum due to pseudocyst. this patient had an indication of drainage.
slide.notesHtml: This is a 41-year-old male, and we could see 2 pseudocysts on the CT. After 7 weeks, he was going through abdominal distension and vomiting, and we could see large distension of the stomach and obstruction of duodenum due to pseudocyst. This patient had an indication of drainage.
slide.text: Case 41/M – duodenal obstruction After 7 wks. Admission

slide.title: Case 41/M – duodenal obstruction
slide.notes: We performed the EUS-guided cystoduodenostomy. After inserting the metal stent and the plastic stent, we could see pus being drained. This is how he recovered after removing the stent.
slide.notesNormalized: we performed the eus-guided cystoduodenostomy. after inserting the metal stent and the plastic stent, we could see pus being drained. this is how he recovered after removing the stent.
slide.notesHtml:
We performed the EUS-guided cystoduodenostomy.

After inserting the metal stent and the plastic stent, we could see pus being drained. This is how he recovered after removing the stent.
slide.text: Case 41/M – duodenal obstruction At 1yr after Tx. Cysto-duodenostomy

slide.title: Case 51/M – Bile duct obstruction
slide.notes: This is a 51-year-old male patient, and we could see the obstruction of his distal bile duct due to pseudocyst. After inserting the plastic stent, his conditions improved.
slide.notesNormalized: this is a 51-year-old male patient, and we could see the obstruction of his distal bile duct due to pseudocyst. after inserting the plastic stent, his conditions improved.
slide.notesHtml:
This is a 51-year-old male patient, and we could see the obstruction of his distal bile duct due to pseudocyst.

After inserting the plastic stent, his conditions improved.
slide.text: Case 51/M – Bile duct obstruction

slide.title: Case 58/M – Fistulization
slide.notes: This is a 58-year-old male patient, and we could see the fistula opening due to pseudocyst. On the CT, he shows defect on the rectum wall. As seen in this case, pancreatitis pseudocyst could form fistula in the pleura and peripheral gut, and this also indicates drainage.
slide.notesNormalized: this is a 58-year-old male patient, and we could see the fistula opening due to pseudocyst. on the ct, he shows defect on the rectum wall. as seen in this case, pancreatitis pseudocyst could form fistula in the pleura and peripheral gut, and this also indicates drainage.
slide.notesHtml: This is a 58-year-old male patient, and we could see the fistula opening due to pseudocyst. On the CT, he shows defect on the rectum wall. As seen in this case, pancreatitis pseudocyst could form fistula in the pleura and peripheral gut, and this also indicates drainage.
slide.text: Case 58/M – Fistulization Cysto-recto fistula Cysto-recto fistula

slide.title: Case 42/M – Bleeding
slide.notes: This is a case of a pseudocyst with bleeding. A surgery should be considered, but in case the patient’s conditions are bad, we should also consider angiography and cysto-gastrostomy.
slide.notesNormalized: this is a case of a pseudocyst with bleeding. a surgery should be considered, but in case the patient’s conditions are bad, we should also consider angiography and cysto-gastrostomy.
slide.notesHtml: This is a case of a pseudocyst with bleeding. A surgery should be considered, but in case the patient’s conditions are bad, we should also consider angiography and cysto-gastrostomy.
slide.text: Case 42/M – Bleeding

slide.title: Indications for Drainage of Pseudocyst ?
slide.notes: This is summary of indication for drainage of pseudocyst. Symptomatic Peripancreatic fluid collection, PFC related infection, Bleeding, Luminal obstruction, Fistulization, Biliary obstruction, Rapid fluid accumulation, and new onset of symptoms.
slide.notesNormalized: this is summary of indication for drainage of pseudocyst. symptomatic peripancreatic fluid collection, pfc related infection, bleeding, luminal obstruction, fistulization, biliary obstruction, rapid fluid accumulation, and new onset of symptoms.
slide.notesHtml: This is summary of indication for drainage of pseudocyst. Symptomatic Peripancreatic fluid collection, PFC related infection, Bleeding, Luminal obstruction, Fistulization, Biliary obstruction, Rapid fluid accumulation, and new onset of symptoms.
slide.text:
Indications for Drainage of Pseudocyst ? 1. Symptomatic PFC - persistent abdominal, flank, or back pain 2. PFC related infection - gas within the collection, presence of debris in pseudocyst 3. Bleeding
4. Luminal obstruction - gastric or duodenal outlet obstruction related to a local mass effect 5. Fistulization
6. Biliary obstruction 7. Rapid fluid accumulation of PFC or pseudocyst on serial imaging 8. New onset of symptoms in a pseudocyst of any size Holt BA, etc. GIE 2015. Puri R, etc. WJGE 2015

slide.title: Standard technique of EUS-guided cystogastrostomy
slide.notes: Next, I will briefly introduce the standard steps of EUS-guided cystogastrostomy . The next speaker, Prof. Lakhtakia will be introducing the device.
slide.notesNormalized: next, i will briefly introduce the standard steps of eus-guided cystogastrostomy . the next speaker, prof. lakhtakia will be introducing the device.
slide.notesHtml:
Next, I will briefly introduce the standard steps of EUS-guided cystogastrostomy .

The next speaker, Prof. Lakhtakia will be introducing the device.
slide.text: Standard technique of EUS-guided cystogastrostomy

slide.title: EUS-guided cystogastrostomy standard technique
slide.notes: There are various ways of drainage in EUS-guided cystogastrostomy depending on the characteristics of pseudocyst: External drainage only, which is rare, internal drainage only, and external & internal performed together.
slide.notesNormalized: there are various ways of drainage in eus-guided cystogastrostomy depending on the characteristics of pseudocyst: external drainage only, which is rare, internal drainage only, and external & internal performed together.
slide.notesHtml: There are various ways of drainage in EUS-guided cystogastrostomy depending on the characteristics of pseudocyst: External drainage only, which is rare, internal drainage only, and external & internal performed together.
slide.text:
EUS-guided cystogastrostomy standard technique External Drainage only - Nasocystic tube
Internal Drainage only - Plastic or Metal Stent or combined
External & Internal

slide.title: EUS-guided cystogastrostomy standard technique (for PS + Nasocystic drainage)
slide.titleNormalized: eus-guided cystogastrostomy standard technique (for ps + nasocystic drainage)
slide.notes: Next is the method of inserting the plastic stent and the nasocystic drainage tube.
slide.notesNormalized: next is the method of inserting the plastic stent and the nasocystic drainage tube.
slide.notesHtml: Next is the method of inserting the plastic stent and the nasocystic drainage tube.
slide.text: EUS-guided cystogastrostomy standard technique (for PS + Nasocystic drainage)

slide.title: Locate cyst under EUS-view Pseudocyst puncture
slide.titleNormalized: locate cyst under eus-view pseudocyst puncture
slide.notes:
Using the first linear EUS, we locate the cyst in good view, and we puncture the pseudocyst wall using the 19-guage needle.
After puncturing, we remove the stylet and aspirate fluid. A sample is sent for Gram stain and culture, cytology, tumor markers or amylase as clinically indicated. The type of drainage is normally determined in accordance with the turbidity of aspirated fluid. Intracystic contrast is rarely required, the main utility is to confirm position in the pseudocyst if suction is dry or the wire dose nod advance or coil.
When we choose a needle, we should consider two points. One is the tendency of peeling off of the guide-wire during manipulation. And another is the stiffness of the needle. I prefer puncturing by Cook, Echo-HD-19-A needle, which has an atraumatic needle tip. So that has a little chance of peeling off of the guide-wire. But the stiffness of needle is still a disadvantage.
slide.notesNormalized:
using the first linear eus, we locate the cyst in good view, and we puncture the pseudocyst wall using the 19-guage needle.
after puncturing, we remove the stylet and aspirate fluid. a sample is sent for gram stain and culture, cytology, tumor markers or amylase as clinically indicated. the type of drainage is normally determined in accordance with the turbidity of aspirated fluid. intracystic contrast is rarely required, the main utility is to confirm position in the pseudocyst if suction is dry or the wire dose nod advance or coil.
when we choose a needle, we should consider two points. one is the tendency of peeling off of the guide-wire during manipulation. and another is the stiffness of the needle. i prefer puncturing by cook, echo-hd-19-a needle, which has an atraumatic needle tip. so that has a little chance of peeling off of the guide-wire. but the stiffness of needle is still a disadvantage.
slide.notesHtml:
Using the first linear EUS, we locate the cyst in good view, and we puncture the pseudocyst wall using the 19-guage needle.

After puncturing, we remove the stylet and aspirate fluid.

A sample is sent for Gram stain and culture, cytology, tumor markers or amylase as clinically indicated.

The type of drainage is normally determined in accordance with the turbidity of aspirated fluid.

Intracystic contrast is rarely required, the main utility is to confirm position in the pseudocyst if suction is dry or the wire dose nod advance or coil.

When we choose a needle, we should consider two points.

One is the tendency of peeling off of the guide-wire during manipulation.

And another is the stiffness of the needle. I prefer puncturing by Cook, Echo-HD-19-A needle, which has an atraumatic needle tip.

So that has a little chance of peeling off of the guide-wire.

But the stiffness of needle is still a disadvantage.
slide.text: Locate cyst under EUS-view Pseudocyst puncture A 19-gauge needle

slide.title: Insertion of guidewire
slide.notes: A 0.025-inch or 0.035-inch by 450-cm wire is passed through the needle and coiled within the cyst cavity.
slide.notesNormalized: a 0.025-inch or 0.035-inch by 450-cm wire is passed through the needle and coiled within the cyst cavity.
slide.notesHtml: A 0.025-inch or 0.035-inch by 450-cm wire is passed through the needle and coiled within the cyst cavity.
slide.text: Insertion of guidewire A 0.025-inch or 0.035-inch

slide.title: Transmural tract dilatation
slide.notes:
Initial transmural tract dilatation is performed mechanically or with electrocautery. I prefer dilatation by wire-guided needle knife. After removal of the EUS needle, we sequentially dilated the tract by passing a triple-lumen needle knife with a 7-Fr shaft diameter. For insertion of Metal sent or nasocystic drainage, a 7 or 8.5 Fr dilatation is enough.
But in order to insert a number of plastic stents, we need sufficient dilatation using a balloon.
slide.notesNormalized:
initial transmural tract dilatation is performed mechanically or with electrocautery. i prefer dilatation by wire-guided needle knife. after removal of the eus needle, we sequentially dilated the tract by passing a triple-lumen needle knife with a 7-fr shaft diameter. for insertion of metal sent or nasocystic drainage, a 7 or 8.5 fr dilatation is enough.
but in order to insert a number of plastic stents, we need sufficient dilatation using a balloon.
slide.notesHtml:
Initial transmural tract dilatation is performed mechanically or with electrocautery.

I prefer dilatation by wire-guided needle knife.

After removal of the EUS needle, we sequentially dilated the tract by passing a triple-lumen needle knife with a 7-Fr shaft diameter.

For insertion of Metal sent or nasocystic drainage, a 7 or 8.5 Fr dilatation is enough.

But in order to insert a number of plastic stents, we need sufficient dilatation using a balloon.
slide.text: Transmural tract dilatation

slide.title: Dilatation of cysto-gastrostomy
slide.notes: This patient had turbid cystic fluid, so we chose to insert the plastic stent and the nasocystic tube. In order to insert an additional guidewire, we had to change to the haber ramp catheter, and after inserting the guidewire additionally, we coiled. Unfortunately, however, the haber ramp catheters are no longer produced, so we need to consider other methods. A 10Fr Soehendra biliary dilator allowed the simultaneous insertion of two guidewires at the initial puncture.
slide.notesNormalized: this patient had turbid cystic fluid, so we chose to insert the plastic stent and the nasocystic tube. in order to insert an additional guidewire, we had to change to the haber ramp catheter, and after inserting the guidewire additionally, we coiled. unfortunately, however, the haber ramp catheters are no longer produced, so we need to consider other methods. a 10fr soehendra biliary dilator allowed the simultaneous insertion of two guidewires at the initial puncture.
slide.notesHtml:
This patient had turbid cystic fluid, so we chose to insert the plastic stent and the nasocystic tube.

In order to insert an additional guidewire, we had to change to the haber ramp catheter, and after inserting the guidewire additionally, we coiled.

Unfortunately, however, the haber ramp catheters are no longer produced, so we need to consider other methods.

A 10Fr Soehendra biliary dilator allowed the simultaneous insertion of two guidewires at the initial puncture.
slide.text: Dilatation of cysto-gastrostomy 10-Fr Soehendra biliary dilatator

slide.title: Insertion of plastic stent and naso-cystic tube
slide.titleNormalized: insertion of plastic stent and naso-cystic tube
slide.notes: In addition, we insert the 7 Fr double-pigtail stent and the naso-cystic tube in order, and we complete the procedure.
slide.notesNormalized: in addition, we insert the 7 fr double-pigtail stent and the naso-cystic tube in order, and we complete the procedure.
slide.notesHtml: In addition, we insert the 7 Fr double-pigtail stent and the naso-cystic tube in order, and we complete the procedure.
slide.text: Insertion of plastic stent and naso-cystic tube

slide.title: Removal of Nasocystic drainage tube
slide.notes: When nasocystic tube drainage decreases, We remove the nasocystic tube.
slide.notesNormalized: when nasocystic tube drainage decreases, we remove the nasocystic tube.
slide.notesHtml:
When nasocystic tube drainage decreases,

We remove the nasocystic tube.
slide.text: Removal of Nasocystic drainage tube

slide.title: Case 41/M Idiopathic chronic pancreatitis (External only)
slide.notes: When procedure is difficult, we could insert the nasocystic tube only, although this method is performed rarely.
slide.notesNormalized: when procedure is difficult, we could insert the nasocystic tube only, although this method is performed rarely.
slide.notesHtml: When procedure is difficult, we could insert the nasocystic tube only, although this method is performed rarely.
slide.text: Case 41/M Idiopathic chronic pancreatitis (External only) At 8th day from intervention

slide.title: Case 54/M (Internal only) FC-SEMSs anchored with a double-pigtail stent
slide.titleNormalized: case 54/m (internal only) fc-semss anchored with a double-pigtail stent
slide.notes:
When there is lots of debridement in the pseudocyst and when it is turbid, we could insert the metal stent, and additional plastic stents in order to prevent migration.
Thanks to the various shapes of newly-designed stents, the necessity for additional insertion of plastic stents is decreasing.
slide.notesNormalized:
when there is lots of debridement in the pseudocyst and when it is turbid, we could insert the metal stent, and additional plastic stents in order to prevent migration.
thanks to the various shapes of newly-designed stents, the necessity for additional insertion of plastic stents is decreasing.
slide.notesHtml:
When there is lots of debridement in the pseudocyst and when it is turbid, we could insert the metal stent, and additional plastic stents in order to prevent migration.

Thanks to the various shapes of newly-designed stents, the necessity for additional insertion of plastic stents is decreasing.
slide.text: Case 54/M (Internal only) FC-SEMSs anchored with a double-pigtail stent Kawakami H, et al. Gut and Liver, 2014

slide.title: Summary
slide.notes: I would like to summarize the indications.
slide.notesNormalized: i would like to summarize the indications.
slide.notesHtml: I would like to summarize the indications.
slide.text: Summary

slide.title: Pancreatic Pseudocyst
slide.notes:
When a patient is diagnosed with pancreatic pseudocyst, and there are no symptoms, cystic infection or rapid size change, we need to consider the conservative management first. If there is any of those conditions, we need to consider the cystogastrostomy.
If cystic neoplasm cannot be excluded, and there is a lack of a safe access route and arterial pseudoaneurysm, we need to consider an OP.
If not, if the patient is cretically ill or if the EUS approach is difficult to be performed concerning the location, we need to consider the PCD. If not, consider the EUS-guided cystogastrostomy.
If there is no infection of cystic fluid and there is no viscosity, plastic stent is enough. If there is, we need to perform external drainage. If an additional necresectomy is considered, it helps to insert the newly-designed FC-CEMS.
slide.notesNormalized:
when a patient is diagnosed with pancreatic pseudocyst, and there are no symptoms, cystic infection or rapid size change, we need to consider the conservative management first. if there is any of those conditions, we need to consider the cystogastrostomy.
if cystic neoplasm cannot be excluded, and there is a lack of a safe access route and arterial pseudoaneurysm, we need to consider an op.
if not, if the patient is cretically ill or if the eus approach is difficult to be performed concerning the location, we need to consider the pcd. if not, consider the eus-guided cystogastrostomy.
if there is no infection of cystic fluid and there is no viscosity, plastic stent is enough. if there is, we need to perform external drainage. if an additional necresectomy is considered, it helps to insert the newly-designed fc-cems.
slide.notesHtml:
When a patient is diagnosed with pancreatic pseudocyst,

and there are no symptoms, cystic infection or rapid size change,

we need to consider the conservative management first.

If there is any of those conditions, we need to consider the cystogastrostomy.

If cystic neoplasm cannot be excluded,

and there is a lack of a safe access route and arterial pseudoaneurysm,

we need to consider an OP.

If not, if the patient is cretically ill or if the EUS approach is difficult to be performed concerning the location, we need to consider the PCD.

If not, consider the EUS-guided cystogastrostomy.

If there is no infection of cystic fluid and there is no viscosity, plastic stent is enough.

If there is, we need to perform external drainage.

If an additional necresectomy is considered, it helps to insert the newly-designed FC-CEMS.
slide.text: Pancreatic Pseudocyst Symptoms, Cystic infection, size change, etc. Conservative Tx. Cystogastrostomy Cystic neoplasm cannot be excluded, Lack of a safe access route, Arterial pseudoaneurysm Consider OP Critically ill Pt.'s or Difficult access of Endoscopy PCD EUS-guided Cystogastrostomy Infection, viscosity Internal drainage only (PS) Internal (PS or MS) + External drainage Consider Necrosectomy New designed FC-SEMS
